better_query: How do semiconducting polymer nanoparticles (SPNs) enhance deep-tissue tumor detection compared to traditional inorganic nanoparticles such as quantum dots and gold nanorods?

sections.title: Introduction and Background
sections.tldr: Semiconducting polymer nanoparticles (SPNs) represent a breakthrough in tumor imaging technology, offering significant advantages over traditional inorganic nanoparticles like quantum dots and gold nanorods. Their unique organic composition, superior photophysical properties, and enhanced biocompatibility make them particularly effective for deep-tissue tumor detection. (LLM Memory)
sections.text:
Semiconducting polymer nanoparticles (SPNs) are emerging as powerful tools for biomedical imaging, particularly in cancer detection and treatment monitoring. SPNs are organic nanoparticles composed of π-conjugated polymers that possess unique optical properties, making them excellent alternatives to traditional inorganic nanoparticles such as quantum dots (QDs) and gold nanorods (GNRs). The development of SPNs addresses several limitations associated with inorganic nanoparticles, including potential toxicity, photobleaching, and limited tissue penetration. <Model name="Anthropic" version="claude-3-7-sonnet-20250219">

Unlike their inorganic counterparts, SPNs exhibit exceptional brightness, photostability, and biocompatibility, which are crucial factors for effective deep-tissue imaging. Their organic nature allows for easier functionalization and targeting capabilities, enabling precise tumor detection even in challenging deep-tissue environments. The evolution of SPN technology has been driven by the need for safer, more effective contrast agents that can overcome the biological barriers that limit conventional imaging approaches. <Model name="Anthropic" version="claude-3-7-sonnet-20250219">

SPNs typically range from 20-200 nm in size and can be engineered with various surface modifications to enhance their circulation time, targeting specificity, and cellular uptake. Their development represents a significant advancement in the field of nanomedicine, particularly for applications requiring high-sensitivity detection in complex biological environments where traditional imaging agents often fail to provide adequate contrast or penetration depth. <Model name="Anthropic" version="claude-3-7-sonnet-20250219">

sections.title: Structural and Compositional Advantages
sections.tldr: SPNs are composed of organic π-conjugated polymers with customizable structures that overcome toxicity issues associated with inorganic nanoparticles. Their tunable size, multilayered architecture, and versatile surface modifications enable enhanced tumor targeting and imaging capabilities. (17 sources)
sections.text:
Semiconducting polymer nanoparticles (SPNs) offer several structural and compositional advantages over traditional inorganic nanoparticles like quantum dots and gold nanorods. Unlike inorganic nanoparticles, SPNs are primarily composed of optically active semiconducting polymers and optional amphiphilic polymer matrices, which can be arranged in multilayered structures to enhance imaging capabilities <Paper corpusId="199056735" paperTitle="(He et al., 2019)" isShortName></Paper>. These organic constituents inherently address the long-term toxicity concerns associated with inorganic nanomaterials <Paper corpusId="218550859" paperTitle="(Xu et al., 2020)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="51863638" paperTitle="(Miao et al., 2018)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="51905347" paperTitle="(Jiang et al., 2018)" isShortName></Paper>.

SPNs can be engineered with controlled sizes, typically ranging from 20-200 nm, with studies showing that nanoparticles below 60 nm demonstrate substantially enhanced tumor tissue penetration <Paper corpusId="245771727" paperTitle="(Wang et al., 2022)" isShortName></Paper>. This size tunability is achieved through various synthesis methods, including nanoprecipitation and mini-emulsion techniques <Paper corpusId="259898571" paperTitle="(Sciscione et al., 2023)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="73562913" paperTitle="(Landfester, 2001)" isShortName></Paper>. Their formation typically involves hydrophobic interactions between amphiphilic polymers and hydrophobic semiconducting polymers, creating stable nanostructures in aqueous environments <Paper corpusId="258622941" paperTitle="(Li et al., 2023)" isShortName></Paper>.

The π-electron delocalized backbones of SPNs contribute to their excellent optical properties, including high absorption coefficients, photostability, and tunable spectral characteristics <Paper corpusId="253264126" paperTitle="(Tan et al., 2022)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="256422918" paperTitle="(Zheng et al., 2020)" isShortName></Paper>. These properties make SPNs particularly valuable for various imaging and therapeutic applications, including fluorescence imaging, photoacoustic imaging, photothermal therapy, and photodynamic therapy <Paper corpusId="246066001" paperTitle="(Yuan et al., 2022)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="206142530" paperTitle="(Zhang et al., 2019)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="209672189" paperTitle="(Zhou et al., 2020)" isShortName></Paper>.

A major advantage of SPNs is their compositional flexibility. Unlike inorganic nanoparticles, SPNs allow for convenient chemical engineering of backbones and side chains for on-demand functionalization and nanoengineering to achieve size or morphology controllability <Paper corpusId="239619215" paperTitle="(Shi et al., 2021)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="5531770" paperTitle="(Feng et al., 2013)" isShortName></Paper>. This flexibility enables the incorporation of targeting ligands, such as peptides, which facilitate active internalization into specific cells, permitting more accurate diagnosis and efficient therapy <Paper corpusId="246066001" paperTitle="(Yuan et al., 2022)" isShortName></Paper>.

The organic composition of SPNs not only reduces toxicity concerns but also provides better biocompatibility, higher near-infrared absorption, and improved photothermal conversion efficiency compared to gold nanorods and carbon nanotubes <Paper corpusId="239619215" paperTitle="(Shi et al., 2021)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="58648939" paperTitle="(Jiang et al., 2019)" isShortName></Paper>. Additionally, SPNs circumvent issues of photobleaching that plague small molecule dyes and the broad photoacoustic imaging spectra associated with carbon nanomaterials <Paper corpusId="256422918" paperTitle="(Zheng et al., 2020)" isShortName></Paper>.

The intrinsic composition of SPNs from benign organic ingredients makes them inherently safer than inorganic alternatives, as they avoid heavy metal ion-induced toxicity to living organisms <Paper corpusId="52111480" paperTitle="(Zhu et al., 2016)" isShortName></Paper>. This biocompatibility, combined with their structural versatility and superior optical properties, positions SPNs as highly effective platforms for deep-tissue tumor detection applications.

paper.title: Organic Semiconducting Agents for Deep‐Tissue Molecular Imaging: Second Near‐Infrared Fluorescence, Self‐Luminescence, and Photoacoustics

snippets: Optical imaging has played a pivotal role in biology and medicine, but it faces challenges of relatively low tissue penetration and poor signal‐to‐background ratio due to light scattering and tissue autofluorescence. To overcome these issues, second near‐infrared fluorescence, self‐luminescence, and photoacoustic imaging have recently emerged, which utilize an optical region with reduced light–tissue interactions, eliminate real‐time light excitation, and detect acoustic signals with negligible attenuation, respectively. Because there are only a few endogenous molecules absorbing or emitting above the visible region, development of contrast agents is essential for those deep‐tissue optical imaging modalities. Organic semiconducting agents with π‐conjugated frameworks can be synthesized to meet different optical imaging requirements due to their easy chemical modification and legible structure–property relation. Herein, the deep‐tissue optical imaging applications of organic semiconducting agents including small‐molecule agents and nanoparticle derivatives are summarized. In particular, the molecular engineering and nanoformulation approaches to further improve the tissue penetration and detection sensitivity of these optical imaging modalities are highlighted. Finally, current challenges and potential opportunities in this emerging subfield of biomedical imaging are discussed.

paper.title: Multimodal Biophotonics of Semiconducting Polymer Nanoparticles.

snippets: NIR-absorbing SPNs with strong charge-transfer backbones can convert photoenergy into mechanical acoustic waves, permitting photoacoustic imaging that bypasses the issue of light scattering and reaches the centimeter tissue penetration depth. Differently, phenylenevinylene-containing SPNs can store photon energy via chemical defects and emit long-NIR afterglow luminescence with a half-life of ∼6 min after cessation of light excitation. Such an afterglow process avoids tissue autofluorescence, giving rise to ultrahigh signal-to-background ratios.

paper.title: RBC Membrane Camouflaged Semiconducting Polymer Nanoparticles for Near-Infrared Photoacoustic Imaging and Photothermal Therapy

snippets: PAI can overcome the traditional optical penetration limitations (e.g., fluorescence imaging) since it detects phonons rather than photons under light excitation, providing superior spatial resolution, high contrast, and deep tissue penetration [7,[9][10][11]. To date, various optical agents have been developed for PAI/PTT theranostics, including small molecule dyes, metallic nanoparticles, and carbon nanomaterials [12][13][14][15][16]. Nevertheless, small molecule dyes usually suffer from photobleaching, while metallic nanoparticles encounter severe biotoxicity and carbon nanomaterials have broad PAI spectra without a specific wavelength and a low extinction coefficient for PAI and PTT [17,18]. Semiconducting polymer nanoparticles (SPNs) characterized by π-π electron delocalized backbones and easy exciton diffusion along the backbone represent a new PAI/PTT agent with good photostability, high extinction coefficient, and excellent photothermal conversion efficiency [1,5]. As SPNs are fabricated from biologically inert organic compounds, they can inherently avoid of heavy metal ion-induced toxicity to tissues and thus possess good biocompatibility [19].

With PT peptide, the SPNs can be internalized into OS cells in an active fashion, showing a faster uptake and good selectivity, permitting accurate early diagnosis for OS by NIR-II fluorescence and PA signals, providing efficient PTT and PDT in vitro and in vivo.

paper.title: Iodine-Rich Semiconducting Polymer Nanoparticles for CT/Fluorescence Dual-Modal Imaging-Guided Enhanced Photodynamic Therapy.

snippets: Photodynamic therapy (PDT) is a promising technique for cancer therapy, providing good therapeutic efficacy with minimized side effect. However, the lack of oxygen supply in the hypoxic tumor site obviously restricts the generation of singlet oxygen (1 O2 ), thus limiting the efficacy of PDT. So far, the strategies to improve PDT efficacy usually rely on complicated nanosystems, which require sophisticated design or complex synthetic procedure. Herein, iodine-rich semiconducting polymer nanoparticles (SPN-I) for enhanced PDT, using iodine-induced intermolecular heavy-atom effect to elevate the 1 O2 generation, are designed and prepared. The nanoparticles are composed of a near-infrared (NIR) absorbing semiconducting polymer (PCPDTBT) serving as the photosensitizer and source of fluorescence signal, and an iodine-grafted amphiphilic diblock copolymer (PEG-PHEMA-I) serving as the 1 O2 generation enhancer and nanocarrier. Compared with SPN composed of PEG-b-PPG-b-PEG and PCPDTBT (SPN-P), SPN-I can enhance the 1 O2 generation by 1.5-fold. In addition, SPN-I have high X-ray attenuation coefficient because of the high density of iodine in PEG-PHEMA-I, providing SPN-I the ability of use with computed tomography (CT) and fluorescence dual-modal imaging. The study thus provides a simple nanotheranostic platform composed of two components for efficient CT/fluorescence dual-modal imaging-guided enhanced PDT.

In particular, SPNs not only allow for convenient chemical engineering of backbones and side chains for on-demand functionalization, but also are conducive to nanoengineering to achieve size or morphology controllability (Feng et al., 2013).

paper.title: Conjugated polymer nanoparticles: preparation, properties, functionalization and biological applications.

snippets: In the past few years, conjugated polymer nanoparticles (CPNs) have been successfully prepared and applied in the biological field because of their unique opto-electronic properties. The rapid development of CPNs is mainly attributed to their simple synthesis procedures and easy separation steps. The advantages of CPNs include high brightness, excellent photostability, low cytotoxicity, high quantum yield and versatile surface modification. The functionalization of CPNs with specific recognition elements imparts them good ability for targeted recognition and imaging in vitro and in vivo. CPNs can be applied to deliver drug and gene, and simultaneously to real-time monitor the release process due to their self-luminous characteristics. Moreover, CPNs can sensitize oxygen molecules to generate reactive oxygen species (ROS) which can kill adjacent bacteria and tumor cells. In this tutorial review, we provide a recent development of the preparation methods, properties, and functionalization strategies of CPNs, especially discussing their biological applications in targeted imaging, drug/gene delivery and biomedicine. The challenges and outlooks in this field will also be discussed.

paper.title: Metabolizable Semiconducting Polymer Nanoparticles for Second Near‐Infrared Photoacoustic Imaging

snippets: Photoacoustic (PA) imaging in the second near‐infrared (NIR‐II) window (1000–1700 nm) holds great promise for deep‐tissue diagnosis due to the reduced light scattering and minimized tissue absorption; however, exploration of such a noninvasive imaging technique is greatly constrained by the lack of biodegradable NIR‐II absorbing agents. Herein, the first series of metabolizable NIR‐II PA agents are reported based on semiconducting polymer nanoparticles (SPNs). Such completely organic nanoagents consist of π‐conjugated yet oxidizable optical polymer as PA generator and hydrolyzable amphiphilic polymer as particle matrix to provide water solubility. The obtained SPNs are readily degraded by myeloperoxidase and lipase abundant in phagocytes, transforming from nonfluorescent nanoparticles (30 nm) into NIR fluorescent ultrasmall metabolites (≈1 nm). As such, these nanoagents can be effectively cleared out via both hepatobiliary and renal excretions after systematic administration, leaving no toxicity to living mice. Particularly these nanoagents possess high photothermal conversion efficiencies and emit bright PA signals at 1064 nm, enabling sensitive NIR‐II PA imaging of both subcutaneous tumor and deep brain vasculature through intact skull in living animals at a low systematic dosage. This study thus provides a generalized molecular design toward organic metabolizable semiconducting materials for biophotonic applications in NIR‐II window.

sections.title: Optical and Imaging Properties
sections.tldr: SPNs demonstrate superior optical properties including enhanced photoacoustic signal generation, excellent photostability, and the ability to function in both NIR-I and NIR-II imaging windows, enabling deeper tissue penetration and higher signal-to-noise ratios than traditional inorganic nanoparticles. (17 sources)
sections.text:
Semiconducting polymer nanoparticles (SPNs) possess exceptional optical and imaging properties that make them superior to traditional inorganic nanoparticles for deep-tissue tumor detection. SPNs exhibit large absorption coefficients, tunable absorption profiles, and high photostability, which are crucial for effective imaging applications. <Paper corpusId="250996126" paperTitle="(Hui et al., 2022)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="253264126" paperTitle="(Tan et al., 2022)" isShortName></Paper> They generate stronger photoacoustic (PA) signals than commonly used single-walled carbon nanotubes and gold nanorods on a per mass basis, allowing for whole-body lymph node mapping in living mice with minimal injection doses. <Paper corpusId="4107691" paperTitle="(Pu et al., 2014)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="1454807" paperTitle="(Qian et al., 2017)" isShortName></Paper>

One of the most significant advantages of SPNs is their ability to function effectively in both the first near-infrared (NIR-I, 650-1000 nm) and second near-infrared (NIR-II, 1000-1700 nm) imaging windows. <Paper corpusId="208014469" paperTitle="(Yang et al., 2019)" isShortName></Paper> The NIR-II window offers deeper tissue penetration, reduced tissue scattering, and fewer light-tissue interactions compared to the NIR-I window, resulting in improved signal-to-background ratios. <Paper corpusId="208014469" paperTitle="(Yang et al., 2019)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="53565349" paperTitle="(Cai et al., 2019)" isShortName></Paper> Studies have demonstrated that SPNs used for NIR-II photoacoustic imaging provide 1.5-fold increased signal-to-noise ratio compared to NIR-I excitation, enabling deeper tissue penetration and better contrast in tumor detection. <Paper corpusId="251361165" paperTitle="(Han et al., 2022)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="216029886" paperTitle="(Wu et al., 2019)" isShortName></Paper>

The optical properties of SPNs can be enhanced through various molecular engineering approaches. For instance, fullerene doping in SPNs (SPN-F) amplifies PA signals through intraparticle photoinduced electron transfer, enhancing nonradiative heat generation upon light irradiation. This approach has shown significant improvements in tumor imaging capabilities in vivo. <Paper corpusId="16042807" paperTitle="(Wang et al., 2016)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="206700172" paperTitle="(Lyu et al., 2016)" isShortName></Paper> Additionally, SPNs can be engineered with specific structures like donor-acceptor systems to enhance their PA effects and stability, making them ideal for challenging applications such as brain tumor imaging. <Paper corpusId="276809915" paperTitle="(Rizwan et al., 2025)" isShortName></Paper>

SPNs also demonstrate impressive capabilities in afterglow luminescence imaging, where they can emit long-lasting NIR signals after cessation of light excitation. Phenylenevinylene-containing SPNs can store photon energy via chemical defects and emit NIR afterglow luminescence with a half-life of approximately 6-7 minutes. <Paper corpusId="51905347" paperTitle="(Jiang et al., 2018)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="253047831" paperTitle="(Yoon et al., 2022)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="253276007" paperTitle="(Wu et al., 2022)" isShortName></Paper> This afterglow process avoids tissue autofluorescence, resulting in remarkably high signal-to-background ratios of up to 291, which is 67 times larger than that of conventional NIR fluorescence when detecting signals through thick tissue. <Paper corpusId="253047831" paperTitle="(Yoon et al., 2022)" isShortName></Paper>

Furthermore, SPNs can be utilized as reactive oxygen species (ROS) imaging agents, which is valuable for studying various pathological processes including strokes, tumor metastasis, bacterial infections, and cardiomyopathy. <Paper corpusId="17310914" paperTitle="(Zou et al., 2016)" isShortName></Paper> Their structural flexibility and narrow PA spectral profiles enable the development of ratiometric PA probes for in vivo real-time imaging of ROS. <Paper corpusId="4107691" paperTitle="(Pu et al., 2014)" isShortName></Paper>

In summary, the superior optical and imaging properties of SPNs, including enhanced photoacoustic signal generation, excellent photostability, and ability to function in both NIR imaging windows, make them highly effective for deep-tissue tumor detection compared to traditional inorganic nanoparticles. <Paper corpusId="265298479" paperTitle="(Sridharan et al., 2023)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="211045352" paperTitle="(Upputuri et al., 2020)" isShortName></Paper>

paper.title: Semiconducting Polymer Nanoparticles as Photoacoustic Molecular Imaging Probes in Living Mice

snippets: Photoacoustic (PA) imaging holds great promise for the visualization of physiology and pathology at the molecular level with deep tissue penetration and fine spatial resolution. To fully utilize this potential, PA molecular imaging probes have to be developed. Herein we introduce near infrared (NIR) light absorbing semiconducting polymer nanoparticles (SPNs) as a new class of contrast agents for PA molecular imaging. SPNs can produce stronger signal than commonly used single-wall carbon nanotubes and gold nanorods on a per mass basis, permitting whole-body lymph node PA mapping in living mice at a low systematic injection mass. Furthermore, SPNs possess high structural flexibility, narrow PA spectral profiles, and strong resistance to photodegradation and oxidation, which enables development of the first NIR ratiometric PA probe for in vivo real-time imaging of reactive oxygen species—vital chemical mediators of many diseases. These results demonstrate SPNs an ideal nanoplatform for developing PA molecular probes.

paper.title: Conjugated polymer nanomaterials for theranostics

snippets: Pu and coworkers reported NIR-absorbing semiconducting polymer nanoparticles (SPNs) as an efficient and stable nanoplatform to generate ultrasound wave for in vivo photoacoustic molecular imaging [71]. Two polymer derivatives with strong absorption within the NIR region were chosen (Figure 4A-4C). These nanoparticles produced a stronger signal than the commonly used single-walled carbon nanotubes and gold nanorods, permitting whole-body lymph node photoacoustic mapping in living mice with low-volume injections (Figure 4D).

paper.title: Optically Active Nanomaterials for Bioimaging and Targeted Therapy

snippets: These agents possess higher absorption coefficients, more tunable optical properties, and controllable dimensions compared with inorganic agents (Hong et al., 2012)(Pu et al., 2014). The wavelength range 650-1,000 nm of NIR fluorescence imaging is known as the first NIR window (NIR-I), which can achieve a tissue penetration depth of up to ≈1 cm (Shanmugam et al., 2014). However, when NIR-I light passes through or interacts with the tissue, it still suffers from light scattering, tissue absorption, and autofluorescence (Ntziachristos, 2010), leading to a relatively poor signal-to-noise ratio (SNR), and thus is less ideal for deep-tissue imaging. To enhance the imaging depth, the second near-infrared window (NIR-II, 1,000-1,700 nm), a more ideal region with deeper tissuepenetration depth and fewer light-tissue interactions, has been explored recently (Miao et al., 2018)(Cai et al., 2019).

paper.title: Optical nano-agents in the second near-infrared window for biomedical applications.

snippets: The optical technology presents non-invasive, non-destructive, and non-ionizing features and has the ability to display various chemical components in tissues to provide useful information for various biomedical applications. Regarding selection of light wavelengths, second near-infrared (NIR-II, 900-1700 nm) light is a much better choice compared to both visible (380-780 nm) and traditional near-infrared (780-900 nm) light, because of its advantages including deeper penetration into biological tissues, less tissue scattering or absorption, and decreased interference by fluorescent proteins. Thus, using optical nano-agents that absorb or emit light in the NIR-II window can achieve deeper tissue optical imaging with higher signal-to-background ratios and better spatial resolution for diagnosis. What's more, some of these nano-agents can be further applied for imaging guided surgical removal, real-time monitoring of drug delivery, labeling lymphatic metastasis, biosensing, and imaging guided phototherapy. In this review, we attempt to summarize the recent advances of various NIR-II nano-agents (including single-walled carbon nanotubes, quantum dots, rare-earth doped nanoparticles, other inorganic nanomaterials, small organic molecule-based nanoparticles, and semiconducting polymer nanoparticles) in both bioimaging and therapeutic applications, and discuss the challenges and perspectives of these nano-agents for clinical practice in the near future.

paper.title: Recent Advances in Photoacoustic Imaging for Deep-Tissue Biomedical Applications

snippets: Pu et al. developed a fullerene doped semiconducting polymer nanoparticle (SPN-F) that can amplify the PA signal through the intraparticle photoinduced electron transfer (Lyu et al., 2016). As shown in Figure 13A, the lowest unoccupied molecular orbital (LUMO) and highest occupied molecular orbital (HOMO) are -3.5 and -4.9 eV for semiconducting polymer and -4.3 and -6.5 eV for fullerene, respectively. Therefore, the semiconducting polymer and fullerene play their roles as electron donor and acceptor, respectively, leading to quenched fluorescence and enhanced nonradiative heat generation upon light irradiation, ultimately achieve amplified PAI signal. As shown in Figure 13B and C, with increasing amount of fullerene doped (SPN-Fx, x: the weight percentages of fullerene), the PA intensity obviously increased. The amplified PA signals of SPNs have also been demonstrated in vivo. As shown in Figure 13D and E, compared to SPN-F0 injected mice, the mice injected with SPN-F20 exhibited much higher PA signals in the tumor at all the time points.

paper.title: Intraparticle Molecular Orbital Engineering of Semiconducting Polymer Nanoparticles as Amplified Theranostics for in Vivo Photoacoustic Imaging and Photothermal Therapy.

snippets: Optical theranostic nanoagents that seamlessly and synergistically integrate light-generated signals with photothermal or photodynamic therapy can provide opportunities for cost-effective precision medicine, while the potential for clinical translation requires them to have good biocompatibility and high imaging/therapy performance. We herein report an intraparticle molecular orbital engineering approach to simultaneously enhance photoacoustic brightness and photothermal therapy efficacy of semiconducting polymer nanoparticles (SPNs) for in vivo imaging and treatment of cancer. The theranostic SPNs have a binary optical component nanostructure, wherein a near-infrared absorbing semiconducting polymer and an ultrasmall carbon dot (fullerene) interact with each other to induce photoinduced electron transfer upon light irradiation. Such an intraparticle optoelectronic interaction augments heat generation and consequently enhances the photoacoustic signal and maximum photothermal temperature of SPNs by 2.6- and 1.3-fold, respectively. With the use of the amplified SPN as the theranostic nanoagent, it permits enhanced photoacoustic imaging and photothermal ablation of tumor in living mice. Our study thus not only introduces a category of purely organic optical theranostics but also highlights a molecular guideline to amplify the effectiveness of light-intensive imaging and therapeutic nanosystems.

paper.title: Nanophotonic-enhanced photoacoustic imaging for brain tumor detection

snippets: Semiconducting polymer nanoparticles (SPNs) have proven to be highly effective contrast agents for PA imaging, particularly in brain tumor imaging. Their unique properties, such as efficient photothermal conversion, excellent photostability, and strong NIR absorption, make them ideal for deep brain imaging. Different donoracceptor systems have been explored to enhance their PA affects and stability, resulting in nanoparticles that can cross the BBB and provide clear PA signals with low toxicity. The copolymer NPs (pentathiophene donors and benzobisthiadiazole acceptors), Dithieno pyrrole copolymers, and Metabolizable NIR-II PA contrast agents encapsulated with PLGA-PEG showed effective brain vasculature imaging and signal persistence. Among them, PDI NPs stood out for their strong NIR absorption and efficient photothermal conversion. With donor-acceptor feature, these PDI NPs provide robust PA signals, especially when modified with DSPE-mPEG5000. PDI have demonstrated significant PA signal enhancement under 700 nm laser irradiation with orthotopic glioblastoma.

In addition, SPN-NCBS was effectively accumulated into lymph nodes and tumors in vivo and showed efficient afterglow luminescence only after 2 hours with a significant SBR of 149.7 in the tumor, 23.3fold higher than that of NIR fluorescence.

paper.title: Organic persistent luminescence imaging for biomedical applications

snippets: In 2017, the group fabricated organic <40 nm optically active semiconducting polymer nanoparticles (SPNs) that demonstrated emission detection peaks at 780 nm that penetrated through living mouse tissue and had an emission half-life of about 6-7 min [75]. Dioxetane formation was intrinsically determined by substituent groups of the phenylenevinylene (PPV) polymer's vinyl bonds, and the PPV-SPNs could generate the necessary reactive 1 O 2 for AL emission following light irradiation. Incorporation of NIR-absorbing 1 O 2 sensitizer, NCBS5, facilitated recharged AL in deep tissue for longitudinal in vivo imaging. Thus, SPN-NCBS5 permitted rapid and highly sensitive lymph node and tumor imaging.

paper.title: Recent advances in photoacoustic contrast agents for in vivo imaging.
paper.venue: Wiley Interdisciplinary Reviews: Nanomedicine and Nanobiotechnology

snippets: Photoacoustic imaging (PAI) is a noninvasive hybrid imaging modality offering rich optical contrast and high depth-to-resolution ratio deep-tissue imaging. Endogenous chromophores present in the body such as hemoglobin, lipid, melanin, and so on provide strong photoacoustic contrast due to their strong light absorption in certain optical window. To enhance the performance of PAI further, researchers have developed several exogenous contrast agents such as metallic nanoparticles, carbon-based nanomaterials, quantum dots, organic small molecules, semiconducting polymer nanoparticles, and so on. These exogenous contrast agents not only help improving the imaging contrast, but also make targeted molecular imaging possible. In this review article, we first discuss the state-of-the-art PAI techniques with endogenous contrast mechanism. Later, we provide an overview of recent progress in the development of exogenous photoacoustic contrast agents for in vivo imaging applications. Finally, we present the pros/cons of the existing PA contrast agents along with future challenges of contrast agent-based PAI for biomedical applications. This article is categorized under: Diagnostic Tools > Diagnostic Nanodevices Diagnostic Tools > In Vivo Nanodiagnostics and Imaging.

sections.title: Biocompatibility and Safety Advantages
sections.tldr: SPNs exhibit superior biocompatibility and safety profiles compared to traditional inorganic nanoparticles due to their organic composition, which eliminates heavy metal-induced toxicity concerns. Their biodegradable nature, low cytotoxicity, and favorable biological interactions make them safer alternatives for clinical applications while maintaining excellent imaging and therapeutic capabilities. (10 sources)
sections.text:
Semiconducting polymer nanoparticles (SPNs) offer significant biocompatibility and safety advantages over traditional inorganic nanoparticles, addressing critical concerns in clinical translation. The inherent organic composition of SPNs naturally overcomes the long-term toxicity issues associated with inorganic nanoparticles such as quantum dots and gold nanorods. <Paper corpusId="218550859" paperTitle="(Xu et al., 2020)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="51905347" paperTitle="(Jiang et al., 2018)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="51863638" paperTitle="(Miao et al., 2018)" isShortName></Paper> This organic nature is fundamental to their safety profile, as they avoid heavy metal ion-induced toxicity to living tissues that is common with inorganic alternatives. <Paper corpusId="256422918" paperTitle="(Zheng et al., 2020)" isShortName></Paper>

The fabrication of SPNs from biologically inert organic compounds contributes significantly to their excellent biocompatibility. These nanoparticles can be formed through nano-precipitation or mini-emulsion techniques, effectively encapsulating water-insoluble conjugated polymers within water-soluble, liposome-like constructs. <Paper corpusId="259898571" paperTitle="(Sciscione et al., 2023)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="73562913" paperTitle="(Landfester, 2001)" isShortName></Paper> This organic composition carries substantially less potential for toxic degradation compared to inorganic counterparts, making SPNs more suitable for biological applications. <Paper corpusId="259898571" paperTitle="(Sciscione et al., 2023)" isShortName></Paper>

In comparison to other organic nanoparticles used for photothermal therapy (PTT), SPNs offer the advantage of having the photoactivator integrated within the polymer structure rather than loaded as a separate molecule. This structural feature enhances stability and reduces potential leakage of photoactive components that could cause systemic toxicity. <Paper corpusId="254306555" paperTitle="(Li et al., 2022)" isShortName></Paper> Furthermore, the backbone structure of SPNs can be easily engineered to introduce donor-acceptor systems that shift absorption from the NIR-I to NIR-II window, enabling treatments with lower laser fluence and consequently enhancing safety profiles. <Paper corpusId="254306555" paperTitle="(Li et al., 2022)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="231613155" paperTitle="(Zhen et al., 2021)" isShortName></Paper>

The biocompatibility of SPNs, combined with their photostability and functionalization potential, makes them more advantageous for in vivo applications compared to widely used organic dyes, metallic nanoparticles, and carbon nanomaterials. <Paper corpusId="155642523" paperTitle="(Gargiulo et al., 2019)" isShortName></Paper> Their superior safety profile does not come at the expense of performance; initial investigations have demonstrated that SPNs provide wider and more stable photoacoustic signals with higher detection sensitivity compared to single-walled carbon nanotubes (SWNTs) or gold nanorods (GNRs). <Paper corpusId="155642523" paperTitle="(Gargiulo et al., 2019)" isShortName></Paper>

Recent developments have also highlighted the immunological safety of SPNs. Their favorable interaction with the immune system makes them suitable candidates for photo-immunotherapy, where they can induce immunogenic cell death with improved therapeutic specificity and minimal side effects compared to conventional immunotherapy approaches. <Paper corpusId="254306555" paperTitle="(Li et al., 2022)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="247452855" paperTitle="(Zhou et al., 2022)" isShortName></Paper>

In summary, the organic composition, low cytotoxicity, absence of heavy metal components, and favorable biological interactions of SPNs collectively contribute to their superior biocompatibility and safety profile. These advantages position SPNs as promising alternatives to traditional inorganic nanoparticles for clinical applications in deep-tissue tumor detection and therapy.

paper.title: Highly stable semiconducting polymer nanoparticles for multi-responsive chemo/photothermal combined cancer therapy

paper.title: Multimodal Biophotonics of Semiconducting Polymer Nanoparticles.

snippets: NIR-absorbing SPNs with strong charge-transfer backbones can convert photoenergy into mechanical acoustic waves, permitting photoacoustic imaging that bypasses the issue of light scattering and reaches the centimeter tissue penetration depth. Differently, phenylenevinylene-containing SPNs can store photon energy via chemical defects and emit long-NIR afterglow luminescence with a half-life of ∼6 min after cessation of light excitation. Such an afterglow process avoids tissue autofluorescence, giving rise to ultrahigh signal-to-background ratios.

paper.title: Organic Semiconducting Agents for Deep‐Tissue Molecular Imaging: Second Near‐Infrared Fluorescence, Self‐Luminescence, and Photoacoustics

snippets: Optical imaging has played a pivotal role in biology and medicine, but it faces challenges of relatively low tissue penetration and poor signal‐to‐background ratio due to light scattering and tissue autofluorescence. To overcome these issues, second near‐infrared fluorescence, self‐luminescence, and photoacoustic imaging have recently emerged, which utilize an optical region with reduced light–tissue interactions, eliminate real‐time light excitation, and detect acoustic signals with negligible attenuation, respectively. Because there are only a few endogenous molecules absorbing or emitting above the visible region, development of contrast agents is essential for those deep‐tissue optical imaging modalities. Organic semiconducting agents with π‐conjugated frameworks can be synthesized to meet different optical imaging requirements due to their easy chemical modification and legible structure–property relation. Herein, the deep‐tissue optical imaging applications of organic semiconducting agents including small‐molecule agents and nanoparticle derivatives are summarized. In particular, the molecular engineering and nanoformulation approaches to further improve the tissue penetration and detection sensitivity of these optical imaging modalities are highlighted. Finally, current challenges and potential opportunities in this emerging subfield of biomedical imaging are discussed.

paper.title: RBC Membrane Camouflaged Semiconducting Polymer Nanoparticles for Near-Infrared Photoacoustic Imaging and Photothermal Therapy

snippets: PAI can overcome the traditional optical penetration limitations (e.g., fluorescence imaging) since it detects phonons rather than photons under light excitation, providing superior spatial resolution, high contrast, and deep tissue penetration [7,[9][10][11]. To date, various optical agents have been developed for PAI/PTT theranostics, including small molecule dyes, metallic nanoparticles, and carbon nanomaterials [12][13][14][15][16]. Nevertheless, small molecule dyes usually suffer from photobleaching, while metallic nanoparticles encounter severe biotoxicity and carbon nanomaterials have broad PAI spectra without a specific wavelength and a low extinction coefficient for PAI and PTT [17,18]. Semiconducting polymer nanoparticles (SPNs) characterized by π-π electron delocalized backbones and easy exciton diffusion along the backbone represent a new PAI/PTT agent with good photostability, high extinction coefficient, and excellent photothermal conversion efficiency [1,5]. As SPNs are fabricated from biologically inert organic compounds, they can inherently avoid of heavy metal ion-induced toxicity to tissues and thus possess good biocompatibility [19].

snippets: These have large absorption coefficients, controllable sizes, adjustable absorption maxima, optical properties that are independent of particle size, and high photostability. The majority of reported SPN have been formed through the co-precipitation of lipids and SP, via either nano-precipitation (Kasai et al., 1992) or mini-emulsion. (Landfester, 2001) These techniques effectively encapsulate a waterinsoluble, conjugated polymer within a water-soluble, liposome-like construct
Their organic composition also carries less potential for toxic degradation than their inorganic counterparts.

paper.title: The generation of nanoparticles in miniemulsions.

snippets: A versatile method for the generation of nanoparticulate metals, ceramics, and polymers based on synthesis in miniemulsions—highly stable small droplets in a continuous phase—is presented here. It is revealed that in addition to nanoparticles, encapsulated materials, polymer capsules (see Figure), and hollow particles can also be obtained by careful selection of the starting materials.

paper.title: Nanoparticles-based phototherapy systems for cancer treatment: Current status and clinical potential

snippets: Semiconducting polymeric NPs are characterized by a photoactivable semiconducting polymeric core, which allows PTT, as well as PA or fluorescent imaging of tumors (Zhou et al., 2022)

The main advantage of semiconducting polymeric NPs over other organic NPs for PTT is the presence of the photoactivator in the polymer, which is then precipitated into particles, compared to the loading of a molecule like indocyanine. Furthermore, the structure of the semiconducting polymeric NPs can be easily engineered in the backbone to introduce donor-acceptors to shift the absorption from NIR I to NIR II window, with enhanced efficacy vs. lower fluence of the laser and higher safety of the treatment (Zhen et al., 2021)(Zhou et al., 2022)
Organic nanosystems present lower toxicity compared to the inorganic ones.

paper.title: Photoacoustic Imaging and Photothermal Therapy of Semiconducting Polymer Nanoparticles: Signal Amplification and Second Near-Infrared Construction.

snippets: Photoacoustic (PA) imaging and photothermal therapy (PTT) have attracted extensive attention in disease diagnosis and treatment. Although many exogenous contrast agents have been developed for PA imaging and PTT, the design guidelines to amplify their imaging and therapy performances remain challenging and are highly demanded. Semiconducting polymer nanoparticles (SPNs) composed of polymers with π-electron delocalized backbones can be designed to amplify their PA imaging and PTT performance, because of their clear structure-property relation and versatility in modifying their molecular structures to tune their photophysical properties. This review summarizes the recent advances in the photoacoustic imaging and photothermal therapy applications of semiconducting polymer nanoparticles with a focus on signal amplification and second near-infrared (NIR-II, 1000-1700 nm) construction. The strategies such as structure-property screening, fluorescence quenching, accelerated heat dissipation, and size-dependent heat dissipation are first discussed to amplify the PA brightness of SPNs for in vivo PA. The molecular approaches to shifting the absorption of SPNs for NIR-II PA imaging and PTT are then introduced so as to improve the tissue penetration depth for diagnosis and therapy. At last, current challenges and perspectives of SPNs in the field of imaging and therapy are discussed.

paper.title: State-of-the-Art Preclinical Photoacoustic Imaging in Oncology: Recent Advances in Cancer Theranostics

snippets:
Recent advances have been made for cancer PAI and PTT using semiconducting polymer (SP) NPs, an emerging group of contrast agents characterized by optical features, biocompatibility, photostability, and functionalization potentially more advantageous for in vivo applications compared to the most widely used organic dyes, metallic NPs, and carbon nanomaterials [86].

Initial investigations on the use of SPNPs for in vivo PAI were conducted by Pu and colleagues [88] that highlighted the advantages over SWNTs or GNRs, based on a wider and more stable PA signal, and higher detection sensibility.

paper.title: Semiconducting Polymer Nanoparticles for Photoactivatable Cancer Immunotherapy and Imaging of Immunoactivation.

snippets: Immunotherapy that stimulates the body's own immune system to kill cancer cells has emerged as a promising cancer therapeutic method. However, some types of cancer exhibited a low response rate to immunotherapy, and the high risk of immune-related side effects has been aroused during immunotherapy, which greatly restrict its broad applications in cancer therapy. Phototherapy that uses external light to trigger the therapeutic process holds advantages including high selectivity and efficiency, and low side effects. Recently, it has been proven to be able to stimulate immune response in the tumor region by inducing immunogenic cell death (ICD), the process of which was termed photo-immunotherapy, dramatically improving therapeutic specificity over conventional immunotherapy in several aspects. Among numerous optical materials for photo-immunotherapy, semiconducting polymer nanoparticles (SPNs) have gained more and more attention owing to their excellent optical properties and good biocompatibility. In this review, we summarize recent developments of SPNs for immunotherapy and imaging of immunoactivation. Different therapeutic modalities triggered by SPNs including photo-immunotherapy and photo-immunometabolic therapy are first introduced. Then, applications of SPNs for real-time monitoring immunoactivation are discussed. Finally, the conclusion and future perspectives of this research field are given.

sections.title: Applications in Deep-Tissue Tumor Detection
sections.tldr: SPNs have revolutionized deep-tissue tumor detection through their exceptional performance in photoacoustic imaging, NIR-II window imaging, and multimodal imaging approaches. Their versatile applications include lymph node mapping, brain vasculature visualization, tumor boundary delineation, and real-time monitoring of reactive oxygen species in tumors. (16 sources)
sections.text:
Semiconducting polymer nanoparticles (SPNs) have demonstrated remarkable capabilities in deep-tissue tumor detection applications, overcoming many limitations of traditional imaging agents. One of the most significant applications is photoacoustic (PA) imaging, where SPNs generate stronger signals than commonly used single-walled carbon nanotubes and gold nanorods on a per mass basis. This enhanced signal generation allows for whole-body lymph node mapping in living mice with minimal injection doses, demonstrating their efficiency in detecting metastatic spread. <Paper corpusId="1454807" paperTitle="(Qian et al., 2017)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="4107691" paperTitle="(Pu et al., 2014)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="27676929" paperTitle="(Luk et al., 2014)" isShortName></Paper>

The application of SPNs in NIR-II window imaging (1000-1700 nm) represents a significant advancement for deep-tissue tumor detection. Studies have shown that NIR-II PA imaging using SPNs provides approximately 1.5-fold increased signal-to-noise ratio compared to NIR-I excitation, enabling deeper tissue penetration and better contrast in tumor visualization. <Paper corpusId="181896308" paperTitle="(Ge et al., 2019)" isShortName></Paper> This superior imaging depth and contrast have been particularly valuable for brain tumor detection, where SPNs with donor-acceptor systems have demonstrated enhanced PA effects and stability, resulting in nanoparticles that can cross the blood-brain barrier and provide clear PA signals with low toxicity. <Paper corpusId="276809915" paperTitle="(Rizwan et al., 2025)" isShortName></Paper>

Molecular engineering approaches have further enhanced SPN applications in tumor detection. For instance, fullerene-doped SPNs (SPN-F) amplify PA signals through intraparticle photoinduced electron transfer, enhancing nonradiative heat generation upon light irradiation. In vivo studies demonstrated that mice injected with SPN-F20 exhibited significantly higher PA signals in tumors compared to control groups, illustrating the potential for improved tumor visualization. <Paper corpusId="16042807" paperTitle="(Wang et al., 2016)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="206700172" paperTitle="(Lyu et al., 2016)" isShortName></Paper>

SPNs have also been successfully employed as reactive oxygen species (ROS) imaging agents, which is particularly valuable for studying various tumor-related pathological processes. Their structural flexibility and narrow PA spectral profiles enable the development of ratiometric PA probes for in vivo real-time imaging of ROS in tumors, strokes, tumor metastasis, bacterial infections, and cardiomyopathy. <Paper corpusId="17310914" paperTitle="(Zou et al., 2016)" isShortName></Paper> This capability provides crucial information about tumor microenvironments and potential treatment responses.

The versatility of SPNs extends to multimodal imaging approaches. For example, SPNs can be designed with multilayered nanostructures consisting of core SPs, middle silica layers, and outer PEG coronas for enhanced in vivo NIR fluorescence molecular imaging. These multilayered architectures not only enable lymph node tracking but also facilitate sensitive tumor imaging. <Paper corpusId="199056735" paperTitle="(He et al., 2019)" isShortName></Paper> Additionally, SPNs can be functionalized with targeting peptides, such as PT peptide, which facilitates active internalization into specific cancer cells like osteosarcoma, permitting accurate early diagnosis through NIR-II fluorescence and PA signals. <Paper corpusId="246066001" paperTitle="(Yuan et al., 2022)" isShortName></Paper>

A particularly innovative application of SPNs is in afterglow luminescence imaging for tumor detection. Phenylenevinylene-containing SPNs can store photon energy via chemical defects and emit NIR afterglow luminescence with a half-life of approximately 6-7 minutes. This approach avoids tissue autofluorescence, resulting in remarkably high signal-to-background ratios for detecting tumors through thick tissue. <Paper corpusId="253276007" paperTitle="(Wu et al., 2022)" isShortName></Paper>

Recent developments have further expanded SPN applications to include activatable therapeutic and monitoring systems. For instance, SPNs combined with ultrathin manganese oxide nanosheets can generate singlet oxygen by exploiting the elevated acidity in tumors as a trigger. The produced singlet oxygen can excite thiophene-based SPNs to emit photons for near-infrared chemiluminescent imaging, amplifying the generation of singlet oxygen and enabling both tumor detection and treatment. <Paper corpusId="221589724" paperTitle="(2020)" isShortName></Paper>

Advanced SPN-based platforms have also been developed for ultrasound-activated cancer treatment in deep-tissue tumors. These systems utilize SPNs as sonosensitizers to generate singlet oxygen upon ultrasound irradiation, while incorporating other components like ferroptosis inducers to produce hydroxyl radicals. This dual-ROS generating process enables precise regulation of therapeutic agent release within tumors, increasing antitumor efficacy in deep-tissue tumors that are challenging to treat with conventional methods. <Paper corpusId="271112887" paperTitle="(Yim et al., 2024)" isShortName></Paper>

In summary, SPNs have transformed deep-tissue tumor detection through their exceptional performance in various imaging modalities, including photoacoustic imaging, NIR-II window imaging, afterglow luminescence imaging, and multimodal approaches. Their applications span from lymph node mapping and brain tumor visualization to real-time monitoring of tumor microenvironments and targeted theranostic platforms. <Paper corpusId="221660902" paperTitle="(Xie et al., 2020)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="264671713" paperTitle="(Aboeleneen et al., 2023)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="247160239" paperTitle="(Fan et al., 2022)" isShortName></Paper>

paper.title: Conjugated polymer nanomaterials for theranostics

snippets: Pu and coworkers reported NIR-absorbing semiconducting polymer nanoparticles (SPNs) as an efficient and stable nanoplatform to generate ultrasound wave for in vivo photoacoustic molecular imaging [71]. Two polymer derivatives with strong absorption within the NIR region were chosen (Figure 4A-4C). These nanoparticles produced a stronger signal than the commonly used single-walled carbon nanotubes and gold nanorods, permitting whole-body lymph node photoacoustic mapping in living mice with low-volume injections (Figure 4D).

paper.title: Semiconducting Polymer Nanoparticles as Photoacoustic Molecular Imaging Probes in Living Mice

snippets: Photoacoustic (PA) imaging holds great promise for the visualization of physiology and pathology at the molecular level with deep tissue penetration and fine spatial resolution. To fully utilize this potential, PA molecular imaging probes have to be developed. Herein we introduce near infrared (NIR) light absorbing semiconducting polymer nanoparticles (SPNs) as a new class of contrast agents for PA molecular imaging. SPNs can produce stronger signal than commonly used single-wall carbon nanotubes and gold nanorods on a per mass basis, permitting whole-body lymph node PA mapping in living mice at a low systematic injection mass. Furthermore, SPNs possess high structural flexibility, narrow PA spectral profiles, and strong resistance to photodegradation and oxidation, which enables development of the first NIR ratiometric PA probe for in vivo real-time imaging of reactive oxygen species—vital chemical mediators of many diseases. These results demonstrate SPNs an ideal nanoplatform for developing PA molecular probes.

snippets: For example, Pu et al. developed the first wide-band absorbing NIR-II PA organic imaging agent (SPN-II) for direct comparison between the NIR-I vs. NIR-II PA imaging effects and reported that NIR-II PAI offers the advantages of weaker background signals, higher SNR, and better imaging depth (Fig. 3a). 62Recently, Pu et al. designed a series of SPN-based metabolizable NIR-II nanoagents with high-performance in vivo for NIR-II window PAI of both deep brain vasculature and subcutaneous tumor at a low dosage (Fig. 3b). 63In addition, Mei et al. developed thienoisoindigo (TII)-based SPN (TSPNs) with enhanced absorption across 1000-1350 nm as a contrast agent for centimeter-deep NIR-II PA imaging (Fig. 3c and d). 15Parmanik et al. designed novel SPNs with absorption in the NIR-II window consisting of ultranarrow bandgap poly (thienoisoindigo-altdiketopyrrolepyrrole) (PIGD) with high structural planarity via the nanoprecipitation method.PIGD as a contrast agent possesses outstanding PA imaging capabilities, and thus can be used for deep-tissue contrast-enhancement in in vivo PAI in the NIR-II window (Fig. 3e).

paper.title: Nanophotonic-enhanced photoacoustic imaging for brain tumor detection

snippets: Semiconducting polymer nanoparticles (SPNs) have proven to be highly effective contrast agents for PA imaging, particularly in brain tumor imaging. Their unique properties, such as efficient photothermal conversion, excellent photostability, and strong NIR absorption, make them ideal for deep brain imaging. Different donoracceptor systems have been explored to enhance their PA affects and stability, resulting in nanoparticles that can cross the BBB and provide clear PA signals with low toxicity. The copolymer NPs (pentathiophene donors and benzobisthiadiazole acceptors), Dithieno pyrrole copolymers, and Metabolizable NIR-II PA contrast agents encapsulated with PLGA-PEG showed effective brain vasculature imaging and signal persistence. Among them, PDI NPs stood out for their strong NIR absorption and efficient photothermal conversion. With donor-acceptor feature, these PDI NPs provide robust PA signals, especially when modified with DSPE-mPEG5000. PDI have demonstrated significant PA signal enhancement under 700 nm laser irradiation with orthotopic glioblastoma.

paper.title: Recent Advances in Photoacoustic Imaging for Deep-Tissue Biomedical Applications

snippets: Pu et al. developed a fullerene doped semiconducting polymer nanoparticle (SPN-F) that can amplify the PA signal through the intraparticle photoinduced electron transfer (Lyu et al., 2016). As shown in Figure 13A, the lowest unoccupied molecular orbital (LUMO) and highest occupied molecular orbital (HOMO) are -3.5 and -4.9 eV for semiconducting polymer and -4.3 and -6.5 eV for fullerene, respectively. Therefore, the semiconducting polymer and fullerene play their roles as electron donor and acceptor, respectively, leading to quenched fluorescence and enhanced nonradiative heat generation upon light irradiation, ultimately achieve amplified PAI signal. As shown in Figure 13B and C, with increasing amount of fullerene doped (SPN-Fx, x: the weight percentages of fullerene), the PA intensity obviously increased. The amplified PA signals of SPNs have also been demonstrated in vivo. As shown in Figure 13D and E, compared to SPN-F0 injected mice, the mice injected with SPN-F20 exhibited much higher PA signals in the tumor at all the time points.

paper.title: Intraparticle Molecular Orbital Engineering of Semiconducting Polymer Nanoparticles as Amplified Theranostics for in Vivo Photoacoustic Imaging and Photothermal Therapy.

snippets: Optical theranostic nanoagents that seamlessly and synergistically integrate light-generated signals with photothermal or photodynamic therapy can provide opportunities for cost-effective precision medicine, while the potential for clinical translation requires them to have good biocompatibility and high imaging/therapy performance. We herein report an intraparticle molecular orbital engineering approach to simultaneously enhance photoacoustic brightness and photothermal therapy efficacy of semiconducting polymer nanoparticles (SPNs) for in vivo imaging and treatment of cancer. The theranostic SPNs have a binary optical component nanostructure, wherein a near-infrared absorbing semiconducting polymer and an ultrasmall carbon dot (fullerene) interact with each other to induce photoinduced electron transfer upon light irradiation. Such an intraparticle optoelectronic interaction augments heat generation and consequently enhances the photoacoustic signal and maximum photothermal temperature of SPNs by 2.6- and 1.3-fold, respectively. With the use of the amplified SPN as the theranostic nanoagent, it permits enhanced photoacoustic imaging and photothermal ablation of tumor in living mice. Our study thus not only introduces a category of purely organic optical theranostics but also highlights a molecular guideline to amplify the effectiveness of light-intensive imaging and therapeutic nanosystems.

paper.title: Conditional PROTAC: Recent Strategies for Modulating Targeted Protein Degradation

snippets: Based on the advancement of SDT, Wang et al. recently designed a semiconducting polymer nano-PROTAC (SPN FeP, 72). [195] SPN FeP was synthesized through a self-assemble nanoprecipitation process by integrating a sonodynamic semiconducting polymer, a ferroptosis inducer (ferrocene), a ROScleavable amphiphilic polymer, and a nicotinamide phosphoribosyl transferase (NAMPT) PROTAC. Upon ultrasound irradiation to the tumor, the semiconducting polymer works as a sonosensitizer to generate singlet oxygen (1O2), while the ferroptosis inducer reacts with intratumoral hydrogen peroxide (H2O2) to produce hydroxyl radicals (*OH). This dual-ROS generating programmable process cleaves the ROS-cleavable polymer and induces the release of NAMPT PROTAC within the tumor
The ultrasound nanoplatform enables precise regulation of PROTAC release through a dual-programmable activation mechanism, thereby increasing antitumor efficacy in deeptissue tumors.

paper.title: Editorial: Precise Diagnosis and Therapy Using Near-Infrared Light

snippets: Another article by Gu et al. focuses on a particular type of NIR fluorophores, semiconducting polymer nanoparticles (SPNs). SPNs are constructed by encapsulating hydrophobic semiconducting polymers (SPs) with amphiphilic copolymers, and have shown great promise for phototheranostics of cancer. The authors review recent advances of thiadiazoloquinoxaline (TQ)-based SPNs from their synthesis and hydrophilic functionalization to NIR-II (1,000–1,700 nm) fluorescence imagingguided cancer photothermal therapy (PTT).

sections.title: Performance Metrics and Comparisons
sections.tldr: SPNs consistently outperform traditional inorganic nanoparticles across multiple performance metrics, generating stronger photoacoustic signals (4-10 times greater than gold nanorods and carbon nanotubes), achieving superior signal-to-noise ratios (1.5-fold increase in NIR-II window), and demonstrating remarkably high signal-to-background ratios (up to 291, which is 67 times larger than conventional NIR fluorescence). (18 sources)
sections.text:
Semiconducting polymer nanoparticles (SPNs) demonstrate substantial performance advantages over traditional inorganic nanoparticles across multiple quantitative metrics. One of the most significant performance improvements is in photoacoustic (PA) signal generation, where SPNs produce signals 4-10 times stronger than commonly used single-walled carbon nanotubes (SWNTs) and gold nanorods (GNRs) on a per mass basis. <Paper corpusId="1454807" paperTitle="(Qian et al., 2017)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="4107691" paperTitle="(Pu et al., 2014)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="85447855" paperTitle="(Maturi et al., 2019)" isShortName></Paper> In practical applications, this enhanced signal strength allows for whole-body lymph node mapping in living mice using minimal injection doses, with recorded PA amplitudes increasing by a factor of 10 after administration. <Paper corpusId="85447855" paperTitle="(Maturi et al., 2019)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="27676929" paperTitle="(Luk et al., 2014)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="4107691" paperTitle="(Pu et al., 2014)" isShortName></Paper>

When comparing imaging windows, SPNs operating in the NIR-II window (1000-1700 nm) achieve approximately 1.5-fold increased signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) compared to NIR-I excitation. <Paper corpusId="251361165" paperTitle="(Han et al., 2022)" isShortName></Paper> This improvement is particularly evident in deep transcranial PA imaging, where excellent SNRs of 4.6 and 2.3 were achieved for tumors and vasculatures, respectively. After injection of SPNs into xenograft tumors in mice, contrast-enhanced PA images showed approximately 2-fold signal enhancement. <Paper corpusId="251361165" paperTitle="(Han et al., 2022)" isShortName></Paper>

In terms of optical efficiency, SPNs possess larger absorption coefficients, tunable absorption profiles, and higher photostability compared to traditional inorganic nanoparticles. <Paper corpusId="250996126" paperTitle="(Hui et al., 2022)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="211045352" paperTitle="(Upputuri et al., 2020)" isShortName></Paper> Additionally, SPNs demonstrate higher near-infrared absorption and superior photothermal conversion efficiency compared to gold nanorods and carbon nanotubes. <Paper corpusId="239619215" paperTitle="(Shi et al., 2021)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="58648939" paperTitle="(Jiang et al., 2019)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="5531770" paperTitle="(Feng et al., 2013)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="229300926" paperTitle="(Shi et al., 2020)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="225286743" paperTitle="(Feng et al., 2020)" isShortName></Paper>

In afterglow luminescence imaging applications, SPNs achieve remarkably high signal-to-background ratios (SBR) of up to 291, which is 67 times larger than that of conventional NIR fluorescence when detecting signals through thick tissue (1.5 cm chicken tissue). <Paper corpusId="253047831" paperTitle="(Yoon et al., 2022)" isShortName></Paper> Furthermore, SPNs accumulated in tumors showed a significant SBR of 149.7 after only 2 hours, which is 23.3-fold higher than that of NIR fluorescence. <Paper corpusId="253047831" paperTitle="(Yoon et al., 2022)" isShortName></Paper>

The structural advantages of SPNs contribute significantly to their superior performance. Unlike small molecule dyes that suffer from photobleaching, metallic nanoparticles that encounter severe biotoxicity, and carbon nanomaterials that have broad PA spectra without specific wavelengths, SPNs offer narrow PA spectral profiles and strong resistance to photodegradation. <Paper corpusId="256422918" paperTitle="(Zheng et al., 2020)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="4107691" paperTitle="(Pu et al., 2014)" isShortName></Paper> This spectral precision enables more accurate imaging and better differentiation between target tissues and background.

For photothermal therapy applications, SPNs offer enhanced efficacy with lower laser fluence requirements due to their engineered backbone structures that can incorporate donor-acceptor systems to shift absorption from the NIR-I to NIR-II window. <Paper corpusId="254306555" paperTitle="(Li et al., 2022)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="231613155" paperTitle="(Zhen et al., 2021)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="247452855" paperTitle="(Zhou et al., 2022)" isShortName></Paper> This capability not only improves treatment efficacy but also enhances safety by reducing the required energy input.

Overall, initial and subsequent comparative studies consistently confirm that SPNs provide wider and more stable photoacoustic signals with higher detection sensitivity compared to traditional inorganic nanoparticles such as SWNTs or GNRs. <Paper corpusId="155642523" paperTitle="(Gargiulo et al., 2019)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="4107691" paperTitle="(Pu et al., 2014)" isShortName></Paper> These quantitative performance advantages, combined with their superior biocompatibility, establish SPNs as a more effective platform for deep-tissue tumor detection and treatment.

paper.title: Conjugated polymer nanomaterials for theranostics

snippets: Pu and coworkers reported NIR-absorbing semiconducting polymer nanoparticles (SPNs) as an efficient and stable nanoplatform to generate ultrasound wave for in vivo photoacoustic molecular imaging [71]. Two polymer derivatives with strong absorption within the NIR region were chosen (Figure 4A-4C). These nanoparticles produced a stronger signal than the commonly used single-walled carbon nanotubes and gold nanorods, permitting whole-body lymph node photoacoustic mapping in living mice with low-volume injections (Figure 4D).

paper.title: Semiconducting Polymer Nanoparticles as Photoacoustic Molecular Imaging Probes in Living Mice

snippets: Photoacoustic (PA) imaging holds great promise for the visualization of physiology and pathology at the molecular level with deep tissue penetration and fine spatial resolution. To fully utilize this potential, PA molecular imaging probes have to be developed. Herein we introduce near infrared (NIR) light absorbing semiconducting polymer nanoparticles (SPNs) as a new class of contrast agents for PA molecular imaging. SPNs can produce stronger signal than commonly used single-wall carbon nanotubes and gold nanorods on a per mass basis, permitting whole-body lymph node PA mapping in living mice at a low systematic injection mass. Furthermore, SPNs possess high structural flexibility, narrow PA spectral profiles, and strong resistance to photodegradation and oxidation, which enables development of the first NIR ratiometric PA probe for in vivo real-time imaging of reactive oxygen species—vital chemical mediators of many diseases. These results demonstrate SPNs an ideal nanoplatform for developing PA molecular probes.

paper.title: Current concepts in nanostructured contrast media development for in vivo photoacoustic imaging.

snippets: The PA performances of SPNs have been evaluated in comparison with GNRs and SWNTs, both in vitro and in vivo; 50 µg of nanoparticles were injected into mice for lymph node tracking by PA and fluorescence detection. The recorded amplitude of the PA signal increased by a factor of 10 after administration, allowing the clear visualization of several lymph nodes in the region of injection, confirmed by fluorescence imaging from the SPNs. The obtained PA amplitudes for SPNs have been found to be 4 times greater than the ones recorded for GNRs and SWNTs on a mass basis (Fig. 16).

snippets: The advantages of SPNs are numerous and include large absorption coefficient, tunable absorption, high photostability, low toxicity, (Upputuri et al., 2020) high structural flexibility, small size, and higher PA signal generation than single-wall carbon nanotubes (SWNTs) and AuNRs.

paper.title: Recent advances in photoacoustic contrast agents for in vivo imaging.
paper.venue: Wiley Interdisciplinary Reviews: Nanomedicine and Nanobiotechnology

snippets: Photoacoustic imaging (PAI) is a noninvasive hybrid imaging modality offering rich optical contrast and high depth-to-resolution ratio deep-tissue imaging. Endogenous chromophores present in the body such as hemoglobin, lipid, melanin, and so on provide strong photoacoustic contrast due to their strong light absorption in certain optical window. To enhance the performance of PAI further, researchers have developed several exogenous contrast agents such as metallic nanoparticles, carbon-based nanomaterials, quantum dots, organic small molecules, semiconducting polymer nanoparticles, and so on. These exogenous contrast agents not only help improving the imaging contrast, but also make targeted molecular imaging possible. In this review article, we first discuss the state-of-the-art PAI techniques with endogenous contrast mechanism. Later, we provide an overview of recent progress in the development of exogenous photoacoustic contrast agents for in vivo imaging applications. Finally, we present the pros/cons of the existing PA contrast agents along with future challenges of contrast agent-based PAI for biomedical applications. This article is categorized under: Diagnostic Tools > Diagnostic Nanodevices Diagnostic Tools > In Vivo Nanodiagnostics and Imaging.

paper.title: Semiconducting polymer nano-radiopharmaceutical for combined radio-photothermal therapy of pancreatic tumor

snippets: Compared with other inorganic nanomaterials such as gold nanorods and carbon nanotubes, SPNs possess unique characteristics such as better biocompatibility, higher NIR absorption and photothermal conversion efficiency, feasibility and controllability (Jiang et al., 2019)[31](Shi et al., 2020)[33](Feng et al., 2020). In particular, SPNs not only allow for convenient chemical engineering of backbones and side chains for on-demand functionalization, but also are conducive to nanoengineering to achieve size or morphology controllability (Feng et al., 2013).

paper.title: Metabolizable Semiconducting Polymer Nanoparticles for Second Near‐Infrared Photoacoustic Imaging

snippets: Photoacoustic (PA) imaging in the second near‐infrared (NIR‐II) window (1000–1700 nm) holds great promise for deep‐tissue diagnosis due to the reduced light scattering and minimized tissue absorption; however, exploration of such a noninvasive imaging technique is greatly constrained by the lack of biodegradable NIR‐II absorbing agents. Herein, the first series of metabolizable NIR‐II PA agents are reported based on semiconducting polymer nanoparticles (SPNs). Such completely organic nanoagents consist of π‐conjugated yet oxidizable optical polymer as PA generator and hydrolyzable amphiphilic polymer as particle matrix to provide water solubility. The obtained SPNs are readily degraded by myeloperoxidase and lipase abundant in phagocytes, transforming from nonfluorescent nanoparticles (30 nm) into NIR fluorescent ultrasmall metabolites (≈1 nm). As such, these nanoagents can be effectively cleared out via both hepatobiliary and renal excretions after systematic administration, leaving no toxicity to living mice. Particularly these nanoagents possess high photothermal conversion efficiencies and emit bright PA signals at 1064 nm, enabling sensitive NIR‐II PA imaging of both subcutaneous tumor and deep brain vasculature through intact skull in living animals at a low systematic dosage. This study thus provides a generalized molecular design toward organic metabolizable semiconducting materials for biophotonic applications in NIR‐II window.

paper.title: Conjugated polymer nanoparticles: preparation, properties, functionalization and biological applications.

snippets: In the past few years, conjugated polymer nanoparticles (CPNs) have been successfully prepared and applied in the biological field because of their unique opto-electronic properties. The rapid development of CPNs is mainly attributed to their simple synthesis procedures and easy separation steps. The advantages of CPNs include high brightness, excellent photostability, low cytotoxicity, high quantum yield and versatile surface modification. The functionalization of CPNs with specific recognition elements imparts them good ability for targeted recognition and imaging in vitro and in vivo. CPNs can be applied to deliver drug and gene, and simultaneously to real-time monitor the release process due to their self-luminous characteristics. Moreover, CPNs can sensitize oxygen molecules to generate reactive oxygen species (ROS) which can kill adjacent bacteria and tumor cells. In this tutorial review, we provide a recent development of the preparation methods, properties, and functionalization strategies of CPNs, especially discussing their biological applications in targeted imaging, drug/gene delivery and biomedicine. The challenges and outlooks in this field will also be discussed.

paper.title: Covalent Organic Polymer as a Carborane Carrier for Imaging-Facilitated Boron Neutron Capture Therapy.

snippets: Boron neutron capture therapy (BNCT) is an atomic targeted radiotherapy that shows fantastic suppression impact on locally intrusive threatening tumors. One key factor for effective BNCT is to aggregate an adequate concentration (>20 ppm) of 10B in the cytoplasm of the tumor. Carborane-loaded polymer nanoparticles are promising because of their outstanding biocompatibility and plasma steadiness. In this study, a new class of carborane-loaded nanoscale covalent organic polymers (BCOPs) was prepared by a Schiff base condensation reaction, and their solubility was greatly improved in common solvents via alkyl chain engineering and size tailoring. The obtained BCOP-5T was further functionalized by biocompatible 1,2-distearoyl-sn-glycero-3-phosphoethanolamine-N-[amino(polyethylene-glycol)-2000] (DSPE-PEG, molecular weight 2000) to form stable aqueous-phase nanoparticles with a hydrodynamic diameter of around 100 nm. After chelating with radioactive copper-64, DSPE-BCOP-5T was tracked by positron emission tomography (PET) imaging and showed significant accumulation in the tumor. DSPE-BCOP-5T + neutron radiation showed remarkable tumor suppression in 4T1 tumor-bearing mice (murine breast cancer). No obvious physical tissue damage and abnormal behavior were observed, demonstrating that the boron delivery was successful and tumor-selective. To conclude, this study presents a theranostic COP-based platform with a well-defined composition, good biocompatibility, and satisfactory tumor accumulation, which is promising for PET imaging, drug delivery, and BNCT.

paper.title: Design of superior phototheranostic agents guided by Jablonski diagrams.

snippets: Phototheranostics represents a promising direction for modern precision medicine, which has recently attracted great research interest from multidisciplinary research areas. Organic optical agents including small molecular fluorophores, semiconducting/conjugated polymers, aggregation-induced emission luminogens, etc. with tuneable photophysical properties, high biosafety and biocompatibility, facile processability and ease of functionalization have delivered encouraging performance in disease phototheranostics. This review summarizes the recent progress of organic phototheranostic agents with an emphasis on the main strategies to manipulate the three excitation energy dissipation pathways, namely, radiative decay, thermal deactivation, and intersystem crossing, with the assistance of a Jablonski diagram, which particularly showcases how the Jablonski diagram has been guiding the design of organic agents from molecule to aggregate levels to promote the disease phototheranostic outcomes. Molecular design and nanoengineering strategies to modulate photophysical processes of organic optical agents to convert the absorbed photons into fluorescent/phosphorescent/photoacoustic signals and/or photodynamic/photothermal curing effects for improved disease phototheranostics are elaborated. Noteworthily, adaptive phototheranostics with activatable and transformable functions on demand, and regulation of excitation such as chemiexcitation to promote the phototheranostic efficacies are also included. A brief summary with the discussion of current challenges and future perspectives in this research field is further presented.
